Delusions of Grandeur is full of people who speak in grandiloquent terms, like the king, who has the power to command the world to do his bidding, but in practice has a powerless, unfulfillable existence: The king was a figure of great power but little consequence. Delusions of Grandeur is full of people who speak of their power and the grandeur of their lives. They are convinced that they are living in a world of their own, that they are the only ones who can see the beauty and grandeur in the world. In Delusions of Grandeur, people speak of "the American century" and its supposedly unassailable advantages. But what exactly is the American Century? Does it exist? And what does it mean for the future of the planet and its inhabitants? In this book, David Wallace-Wells, author of The Unincorporated, argues that the American Century is not a real, historical phenomenon, but a product of the way that the US uses its power
